title: Perseid meteor shower 2025: Best times and locations for viewing
description: Scientists predict up to 50 meteors per hour during peak viewing times.
content:
The much-anticipated Perseid meteor shower, one of nature's most dazzling sky shows, is set to peak Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, lighting up skies across the Northern Hemisphere.

"The Perseids are caused by Earth running into trails of debris left behind by Comet Swift-Tuttle," Bill Cooke, lead for NASA's Meteoroid Environments Office, told ABC News.

The shower has been captivating humans since it was first recorded by Chinese astronomers in 36 A.D., nearly 2,000 years ago.

For the best view of this celestial spectacle, timing is everything.

"The best time to see the Perseids would be in the wee hours of [Wednesday] morning, around 2 to 4 a.m.," Cooke said.

If you want to catch the show you won't need a telescope, Cooke said.

"You definitely do not want to use a telescope or binoculars, as the best way to see a meteor shower is to take in as much sky as possible," Cooke advised. "Just use your eyes and enjoy the show!"

While this year's display will be affected by moonlight, determined sky-watchers can still catch plenty of meteors.

"The average person under dark skies could see somewhere between 40 and 50 Perseids per hour," Cooke said. "Instead, you're probably going to see 10 to 20 per hour or fewer."

These "shooting stars" are actually space debris from Comet Swift-Tuttle, which last visited our cosmic neighborhood in 1992, according to NASA press release. (The comet is named for the two scientists who discovered the comet in 1862, Lewis Swift and Horace Tuttle).

When these pieces hit Earth's atmosphere, they create brilliant streaks of light across the night sky. The shower gets its name because the meteors appear to shoot out from near the Perseus constellation, NASA said.

For the best viewing experience, find a safe, dark spot away from city lights with a wide view of the sky. The shower will remain active until Sept. 1, though Tuesday night offers peak viewing opportunities. Just remember to dress warmly, bring a comfortable chair and give your eyes about 30 minutes to adjust to the darkness.

"You're not going to see Perseids around suppertime," Cooke said. "You're going to have to go out later."

But for those willing to stay up late, the celestial show promises to be worth the wait.
summary: The Perseid meteor shower, one of nature's most dazzling sky shows, is set to peak Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, lighting up skies across the Northern Hemisphere. The best viewing time is around 2 to 4 a.m. While this year's display will be affected by moonlight, determined sky-watchers can still catch plenty of meteors. The shower, named after Comet Swift-Tuttle, will remain active until Sept. 1.
shortSummary: The Perseid meteor shower peaks Tuesday night, with peak viewing expected in the early hours, and requires no telescope to view it.

scraped_sources.text:
Taylor Swift will appear on Travis and Jason Kelce's 'New Heights' podcast
The new episode of "New Heights" will arrive on Wednesday at 7 p.m. ET.
Are you ready for it? Taylor Swift is joining the New Heights podcast with Travis Kelce.
On Monday night, New Heights shared a video of Kelce and Swift on Instagram teasing the upcoming episode. Watch here.
Swift appears, telling boyfriend Travis Kelce, who is wearing a blue hoodie, "It's such a nice color on you."
He replies, "Yeah, it's the color of your eyes, sweetie. That's why we match so well."
"We're about to do a f---ing podcast!" Swift adds.
The news comes after tons of speculation earlier on Monday that Swift would make a guest appearance on the show.
The "New Heights" podcast, which is co-hosted by Travis and his brother Jason Kelce, teased on social media that "a special episode with a VERY special guest" will be released on Wednesday.
They illustrated the post with a picture of Jason wearing an Eras Tour tee and a vaguely Swift-shaped silhouette.
Soon after that post went up, the official fan site Taylor Nation posted, "Thinking about when she said 'See you next era.'"
The post featured a number of onstage photos showing Swift wearing orange during the Eras Tour -- the same background color that was used on the New Heights post.
All this has, of course, convinced Swifties that she may use an appearance on New Heights to announce her next album.
While Swift has never appeared on the brothers' podcast, she's been mentioned a few times on the show.
In July 2023, Travis Kelce talked about how he wanted to give Swift a friendship bracelet at her concert with his number on it.
He also reacted to the time she attended her first Chiefs game in September 2023.
After Travis Kelce made a cameo during the Eras Tour in June 2024 in London, he also spoke about the experience on the podcast and said "it was awesome."
In January, Travis Kelce said Swift "listens every week" to the "New Heights" podcast.
The next "New Heights" podcast with Swift arrives on Wednesday at 7 p.m. ET.

argos_summary: The Perseid meteor shower is expected to peak on Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, providing a spectacular display across the Northern Hemisphere. Viewers are advised to watch between 2 and 4 a.m. for the best chance to see 10 to 20 meteors per hour, despite some interference from moonlight. The meteors originate from debris left by Comet Swift-Tuttle, and the shower will remain active until September 1.
